sen.j: 三味線（しゃみせん）は、日本の有棹弦楽器。
sen.e: Shamisen is a Japanese stringed musical instrument with the neck.
sen.cmt: 用語検索で「有棹弦楽器」は"yutogengakki (longuria arcochordae type of stringed music instrument)"となっていますが、英語版のYAHOO!やGoogleで"longuria arcochordae"を検索しても日本語のサイトしかヒットしないため、この用語は使用しませんでした。
sen.e: Shamisen is a Japanese stringed musical instrument with a neck.
Shamisen is a Japanese stringed musical instrument with a neck.

sen.j: もっぱらはじいて演奏される撥弦楽器である。
sen.e: It is a plucked string instrument.
It is a plucked string instrument.
It is a plucked string instrument.

sen.j: 四角状の扁平な木製の胴の両面に皮を張り、胴を貫通して伸びる棹に張られた弦を、通常、イチョウ形の撥（ばち）で弾き演奏する。
sen.e: The wooden body is square and flat, and the both sides of it are covered with skin; the neck extends through the body, on which strings are plucked to play with bachi (a plectrum) shaped like a ginkgo leaf.
The wooden body is square and flat, and both sides are covered with skin; the neck extends through the body, on which strings are plucked with a bachi (a plectrum) shaped like a ginkgo leaf.
The wooden body is square and flat, and both sides are covered with skin; the neck extends through the body, on which strings are plucked with a bachi (a plectrum) shaped like a ginkgo leaf.

sen.j: 成立は15世紀から16世紀にかけてとされ、和楽器の中では、比較的歴史が浅いと言える。
sen.e: It probably originated between 15th and 16th century, having a relatively short history for a traditional Japanese musical instrument.
It probably originated between fifteenth and sixteenth century, having a relatively short history for a traditional Japanese musical instrument.
It probably originated between fifteenth and sixteenth century, having a relatively short history for a traditional Japanese musical instrument.

sen.j: 基本的にはヘラ状の撥を用いるが、三味線音楽の種目により細部に差異がある。
sen.e: Generally, it is played with bachi in the shape of a spatula, but there are fine differences depending on the item of shamisen music.
Generally, it is played with a bachi in the shape of a spatula, but there are fine differences depending upon the rendition of shamisen music.
Generally, it is played with a bachi in the shape of a spatula, but there are fine differences depending upon the rendition of shamisen music.

sen.j: 近世邦楽の世界、特に地歌・箏曲の世界（三曲）等では「三弦（さんげん）」、または「三絃」と呼称し、表記する事も多い。
sen.e: In the world of traditional Japanese music of the early-modern times, especially the world of jiuta (a genre of traditional songs with shamisen accompaniment), sokyoku (koto music) (combined with kokyu (Chinese fiddle) music, they are called "sankyoku" (instrumental trio)), and so on; shamisen is sometimes called 'sangen' (a three-stringed musical instrument), written as '三弦' or '三絃.'

In the world of traditional Japanese music of the early-modern times, especially the world of jiuta (a genre of traditional songs with shamisen accompaniment), sokyoku (koto music) (combined with the kokyu (Chinese fiddle) music, they are called "sankyoku" or instrumental trio), and so on; shamisen is sometimes called 'sangen' (a three-stringed musical instrument), written as '三弦' or '三絃.'

In the world of traditional Japanese music of the early-modern times, especially the world of jiuta (a genre of traditional songs with shamisen accompaniment), sokyoku (koto music) (combined with the kokyu (Chinese fiddle) music, they are called "sankyoku" or instrumental trio), and so on; shamisen is sometimes called 'sangen' (a three-stringed musical instrument), written as '三弦' or '三絃.'

sen.j: 雅語として「みつのお（三つの緒）」と呼ばれることもある。
sen.e: It is also called 'mitsuno-o' as a classical expression.
sen.cmt: 用語検索で「みつのお」は"mitsunoo (shamisen, a three-stringed musical instrument)"となっていますが、長音と区別するため、"mitsunoo"→"mitsuno-o"としました。
sen.e: It is also called 'mitsuno-o' as a classical expression.
It is also called 'mitsuno-o' as a classical expression.

sen.j: 沖縄県や鹿児島県奄美諸島では三線（さんしん）とも呼ぶ。
sen.e: In Okinawa Prefecture and Amami islands of Kagoshima Prefecture, it is also called sanshin.
In Okinawa Prefecture and Amami islands of Kagoshima Prefecture, it is also called sanshin.
In Okinawa Prefecture and Amami islands of Kagoshima Prefecture, it is also called sanshin.

sen.j: 楽器本体は「天神」（糸倉）、「棹」（ネック）、「胴」（ボディ）から成る。
sen.e: The instrument itself consists of 'tenjin' (or itogura: pegbox), 'sao' (neck), and 'do' (body).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The instrument itself consists of 'tenjin' (or itogura: pegbox), 'sao' (neck), and 'do' (body).
The instrument itself consists of 'tenjin' (or itogura: pegbox), 'sao' (neck), and 'do' (body).

sen.j: さらに棹は上棹、中棹、下棹の3つに分割出来るものが多く、このような棹を「三つ折れ」という。
sen.e: Many sao are divided into three parts: kamizao, nakazao, and shimozao, and this kind of sao is called 'mitsuore' (threefold).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Many sao are divided into three parts: kamizao, nakazao, and shimozao, and this kind of sao is called 'mitsuore' (threefold).
Many sao are divided into three parts: kamizao, nakazao, and shimozao, and this kind of sao is called 'mitsuore' (threefold).

sen.j: これは主に収納や持ち運びの便のため、また棹に狂いが生じにくくするためである。
sen.e: It is mainly designed for storage and portability, and also to prevent sao from getting warped.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is mainly designed for storage and portability, and also to prevent sao from becoming warped.
It is mainly designed for storage and portability, and also to prevent sao from becoming warped.

sen.j: 分割されていないものもあり「延棹（のべざお）」と称する。
sen.e: Sao without division is called 'nobezao.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Sao without division is called 'nobezao.'
Sao without division is called 'nobezao.'

sen.j: 逆に5つ以上に分割できるものもある。
sen.e: On the other hand, some sao are divided into more than five parts.
On the other hand, some sao are divided into more than five parts.
On the other hand, some sao are divided into more than five parts.

sen.j: 素材には高級品ではコウキ（こうき）材（インド産）を用いるが、シタン（したん）、カリン (マメ科)（かりん）材（タイ・ミャンマー・ラオスなどの東南アジア産）の棹もある。
sen.e: The material used for high-grade articles is koki (a kind of tree) (grown in India); there are also other kinds of sao made of rosewood or quince (grown in Southeast Asia including Thailand, Myanmar, and Laos).
sen.cmt: 原文には「カリン（マメ科）」とありますが、（マメ科）はリンク先でしたので訳出しませんでした。また、ウェブでは「コウキ」「シタン」「カリン」はそれぞれ「紅木」「紫檀」「花林」と漢字で表記されています。
sen.e: The material used for high-grade instruments is koki (a kind of tree) (grown in India); there are also other kinds of sao made of rosewood or quince (grown in Southeast Asia including Thailand, Myanmar, and Laos).

The material used for high-grade instruments is koki (a kind of tree) (grown in India); there are also other kinds of sao made of rosewood or quince (grown in Southeast Asia including Thailand, Myanmar, and Laos).

sen.j: 以前はカシ、クワ製も多かった。
sen.e: In the past, there were also many sao made of oak or mulberry.
In the past, there were also many sao made of oak or mulberry.
In the past, there were also many sao made of oak or mulberry.

sen.j: 最近一部ではスネークウッドを使うこともある。
sen.e: Nowadays, some sao are made of snakewood.
Nowadays, some sao are made of snakewood.
Nowadays, some sao are made of snakewood.

sen.j: 特殊なものとしてビャクダン（びゃくだん）やタガヤサン（たがやさん）を使うこともある。
sen.e: For some unique articles, sandalwood and Bombay black wood are also used.
sen.cmt: ウェブでは「ビャクダン」「タガヤサン」はそれぞれ「白檀」「鉄刀木」と漢字で表記されています。
sen.e: For some unique articles, sandalwood and Bombay black wood are also used.
For some unique articles, sandalwood and Bombay black wood are also used.

sen.j: 固く緻密で比重の高い木が良いとされる。
sen.e: Wood suitable for making sao is hard, fine-grained, and of high specific gravity.
Wood suitable for making sao is hard, fine-grained, and of a high specific gravity.
Wood suitable for making sao is hard, fine-grained, and of a high specific gravity.

sen.j: 胴は全て花林製だが昔は桑、ケヤキのものもあった。
sen.e: Do are all made of quince, but there were the ones made of mulberry and Japanese zelkova in the old days.
Do are all made of quince, but there were some made of mulberry and Japanese zelkova in the old days.
Do are all made of quince, but there were some made of mulberry and Japanese zelkova in the old days.

sen.j: 上級品では、内側の面に鑿（のみ）で細かな模様を一面に彫り込む。
sen.e: Higher-grade articles have a minute pattern chiseled all over the inner surface of do.
Higher-grade instruments have a minute pattern carved all over the inner surface of the do.
Higher-grade instruments have a minute pattern carved all over the inner surface of the do.

sen.j: これを「綾杉」といい、響きを良くするといわれている。
sen.e: This pattern is called 'ayasugi', which improves the quality of its sound.
This pattern is called 'ayasugi', which improves the quality of its sound.
This pattern is called 'ayasugi', which improves the quality of its sound.

sen.j: 皮は一般にネコの腹を使用していたが、高価な事と生産量の減少により現在は稽古用など全体の7割程度が犬の皮を使用している。
sen.e: Although abdominal skin of cats had been generally used, because of its high price and decline in production, nowadays dogs' skin are used for practice shamisen and others, accounting for 70% of the total.

Although the abdominal skin of cats had been generally used, because of its high price and decline in production, nowadays dog skin is used for practice shamisen and others, accounting for seventy-percent of the total.

Although the abdominal skin of cats had been generally used, because of its high price and decline in production, nowadays dog skin is used for practice shamisen and others, accounting for seventy-percent of the total.

sen.j: また津軽三味線は例外を除き犬皮を使用する。
sen.e: For Tsugaru-jamisen (Tsugaru-shamisen), with some exceptions, dogs' skin is used.
For Tsugaru-jamisen (Tsugaru-shamisen), with some exceptions, dog skin is used.
For Tsugaru-jamisen (Tsugaru-shamisen), with some exceptions, dog skin is used.

sen.j: 合成製品を使用する場合もあるが、音質に劣るため好まれない。
sen.e: Synthetic skin is also used sometimes, but it is not preferred because its tone quality is inferior to real one's.
Synthetic skin is also used sometimes, but it is not preferred because its tone quality is inferior to natural skin.
Synthetic skin is also used sometimes, but it is not preferred because its tone quality is inferior to natural skin.

sen.j: 雌猫は交尾の際、雄猫に皮を引っ掛かれてしまうため雌猫の皮を用いる場合は交尾未経験の個体を選ぶ事が望ましいと言われているが、実際には交尾前の若猫の皮は薄い為、傷の治ったある程度の厚みの有る皮を使用することが多い。
sen.e: When the skin of a she-cat is used for shamisen, it is said that a virgin cat is ideal because she-cats get their skin scratched by tomcats during mating; in fact, the skin of young she-cats before mating is too thin, so slightly thick skin after the scratch healed is often used.

When the skin of a rfemale-cat is used for shamisen, it is said that a virgin cat is ideal because she-cats get their skin scratched by tomcats during mating; in fact, the skin of young female-cats before mating is too thin, so a slightly thick skin after the scratch healed is often used.

When the skin of a female-cat is used for shamisen, it is said that a virgin cat is ideal because she-cats get their skin scratched by tomcats during mating; in fact, the skin of young female-cats before mating is too thin, so a slightly thick skin after the scratch healed is often used.

sen.j: 糸（弦）は三本で、絹製。
sen.e: Shamisen has three strings made of silk.
Shamisen has three strings made of silk.
Shamisen has three strings made of silk.

sen.j: 津軽三味線に関しては、ナイロン・テトロン製の糸を用いる事もある。
sen.e: For Tsugaru-jamisen, nylon or Tetoron (a registered trademark of Teijin for a kind of polyester fiber) strings are also used.
For Tsugaru-jamisen, nylon or Tetoron (a registered trademark of Teijin for a kind of polyester fiber) strings are also used.
For Tsugaru-jamisen, nylon or Tetoron (a registered trademark of Teijin for a kind of polyester fiber) strings are also used.

sen.j: 太い方から順に「一の糸」「二の糸」「三の糸」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In descending order of thickness, they are called 'ichi no ito' (the first string), 'ni no ito' (the second string), and 'san no ito' (the third string), respectively.
In descending order of thickness, they are called 'ichi no ito' (the first string), 'ni no ito' (the second string), and 'san no ito' (the third string), respectively.
In descending order of thickness, they are called 'ichi no ito' (the first string), 'ni no ito' (the second string), and 'san no ito' (the third string), respectively.

sen.j: それぞれ様々な太さがあり、三味線音楽の種目ごとに使用するサイズが異なる。
sen.e: Each string has a variety of thickness, and the size to use depends on the item of shamisen music.
Each string varies in thickness, and the size to use depends on the rendition of shamisen music.
Each string varies in thickness, and the size to use depends on the rendition of shamisen music.

sen.j: 通常、一の糸の巻き取り部の近くに「さわり」と呼ばれるしくみがある。
sen.e: An ordinary shamisen has a mechanism called 'sawari' near the tuning peg of ichi no ito.
An ordinary shamisen has a mechanism called 'sawari' near the tuning peg of ichi no ito.
An ordinary shamisen has a mechanism called 'sawari' near the tuning peg of ichi no ito.

sen.j: これは一の糸の開放弦をわずかに棹に接触させることによって「ビーン」という音を出させるもので、倍音成分を増やして音色に味を付け、響きを延ばす効果がある。
sen.e: This mechanism makes the instrument twang by the open string of ichi no ito touching sao slightly, increasing harmonic overtones to sound more appealing and sustain long.
This mechanism makes the instrument twang from the open string of ichi no ito touching the sao slightly, increasing harmonic overtones to sound more appealing and sustains longer.
This mechanism makes the instrument twang from the open string of ichi no ito touching the sao slightly, increasing harmonic overtones to sound more appealing and sustains longer.

sen.j: これによって発する音は一種のノイズであるが、三味線の音には欠かせないものである。
sen.e: Although the sound caused by this is a kind of noise, it is indispensable for shamisen music.
Although the sound caused by this is a kind of noise, it is indispensable for shamisen music.
Although the sound caused by this is a kind of noise, it is indispensable for shamisen music.

sen.j: 「さわり」の機構を持つ楽器は琵琶など他にもあるが、三味線の特徴は一の糸のみに「さわり」がついているにもかかわらず、二の糸や三の糸の特定の押さえる場所にも（調弦法により変化する）、共鳴によって同様の効果をもつ音があることである。
sen.e: Although biwa and some other instruments also have 'sawari,' shamisen, unlike other instruments, has 'sawari' only for ichi no ito, but ni no it and san no ito also have sounds of the same effects caused by resonance on certain points (which change according to tunings) to hold down the strings.

Although biwa and some other instruments also have 'sawari,' shamisen, unlike other instruments, has 'sawari' only for ichi no ito, but ni no it and san no ito also have sounds of the same effects caused by resonance on certain points (which change according to tunings) to hold down the strings.

Although biwa and some other instruments also have 'sawari,' shamisen, unlike other instruments, has 'sawari' only for ichi no ito, but ni no ito and san no ito also have sounds of the same effects caused by resonance on certain points (which change according to tunings) to hold down the strings.

sen.j: これにより響きが豊かになるとともに、調弦の種類により共鳴する音が変わるので、その調弦法独特の雰囲気をかもし出す要因ともなっている。
sen.e: This makes the sound rich and, because the sound to resonate differ with the type of tuning, creates an atmosphere distinctive of the tuning.
This makes the sound rich and, because the sound resonates differently with the type of tuning, it creates an atmosphere distinctive of the tuning.
This makes the sound rich and, because the sound resonates differently with the type of tuning, it creates an atmosphere distinctive of the tuning.

sen.j: 「東さわり」と呼ばれる棹に埋め込んだ、螺旋式のさわりもある。
sen.e: There is a screw type sawari implanted in sao, called 'azuma sawari.'
There is a screw type sawari implanted in sao, called 'azuma sawari.'
There is a screw type sawari implanted in sao, called 'azuma sawari.'

sen.j: 三味線にあっては、調弦は複数のパターンがあり、ヴァイオリン等と異なり、曲によって、また曲の途中でも調弦を変化させる。
sen.e: There are several tunings for shamisen and, unlike violin and some other instruments, shamisen is tuned up according to the music, even during the performance.
There are several types of tuning for shamisen and, unlike violin and some other instruments, shamisen is tuned up according to the music, even during the performance.
There are several types of tuning for shamisen and, unlike violin and some other instruments, shamisen is tuned up according to the music, even during the performance.

sen.j: 基本の調弦は次の通りである。
sen.e: Basic tunings are as follows.
Basic tuning is as follows.
Basic tuning is as follows.

sen.j: 調弦法が多種あるのは、異なる調に対応するためと、響きによる雰囲気の違いのためである（詳しくは「地歌」を参照）。
sen.e: There are various tunings to cover every different keys, and also to create different atmosphere depending on the tuning (See also 'Jiuta' for details).
There are various kinds of tuning to cover every different key, and also to create a different atmosphere depending upon the tuning (See also 'Jiuta' for details).
There are various kinds of tuning to cover every different key, and also to create a different atmosphere depending upon the tuning (See also 'Jiuta' for details).

sen.j: 本調子 - 一の糸に対し、二の糸を完全４度高く、三の糸をオクターブ高く合わせる。
sen.e: Hon-choshi (the basic tuning method) -Ni no ito is tuned a perfect forth above ichi no ito, with san no ito an octave above.
sen.cmt: 原文には「音程」とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「完全４度」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: Hon-choshi (the basic tuning method) -Ni no ito is tuned a perfect forth above ichi no ito, with san no ito an octave above.
Hon-choshi (the basic tuning method) -Ni no ito is tuned a perfect forth above ichi no ito, with san no ito an octave above.

sen.j: 一の糸がCならば二の糸はF、三の糸は高いCとなる。
sen.e: If ichi no ito is C, ni no ito is F and san no ito is C of an octave higher.
If ichi no ito is C, ni no ito is F and san no ito is C of an octave higher.
If ichi no ito is C, ni no ito is F and san no ito is C of an octave higher.

sen.j: 二上がり - 一の糸に対し、二の糸を完全５度高く、三の糸をオクターブ高く合わせる。
sen.e: Ni-agari (the second raised) - Ni no ito is tuned a perfect fifth above ichi no ito, with san no ito an octave above.
sen.cmt: 原文には「音程」とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「完全５度」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: Ni-agari (the second raised) - Ni no ito is tuned a perfect fifth above ichi no ito, with san no ito an octave above.
Ni-agari (the second raised) - Ni no ito is tuned a perfect fifth above ichi no ito, with san no ito an octave above.

sen.j: 本調子の二の糸を上げるとこの調子になる事から。
sen.e: The name came from that this tuning is done by raising ni no it from hon-choshi.
The name came from the idea that tuning is done by raising ni no it from hon-choshi.
The name came from the idea that tuning is done by raising ni no it from hon-choshi.

sen.j: 沖縄県では「二上げ」とも言う。
sen.e: It is also called 'Ni-age' in Okinawa Prefecture.
It is also called 'Ni-age' in Okinawa Prefecture.
It is also called 'Ni-age' in Okinawa Prefecture.

sen.j: C-G-Cとなる。
sen.e: The strings are tuned C-G-C.
The strings are tuned C-G-C.
The strings are tuned C-G-C.

sen.j: 三下がり - 一の糸に対し、二の糸を完全4度高く、三の糸を短７度高く合わせる。
sen.e: San-sagari (the third lowered) - Ni no ito is tuned a perfect forth above ichi no ito, with san no ito an minor seventh below.
sen.cmt: 原文には「音程」とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「短７度」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: San-sagari (the third lowered) - Ni no ito is tuned a perfect forth above ichi no ito, with san no ito a minor seventh below.
San-sagari (the third lowered) - Ni no ito is tuned a perfect forth above ichi no ito, with san no ito a minor seventh below.

sen.j: 本調子の三の糸を下げるとこの調子になる事から。
sen.e: The name came from that this tuning is done by lowering san no it from hon-choshi.
The name came from the idea that tuning is done by lowering san no it from hon-choshi.
The name came from the idea that tuning is done by lowering san no ito from hon-choshi.

sen.j: 沖縄県では「三下げ」とも言う。
sen.e: It is also called 'San-sage' in Okinawa Prefecture.
It is also called 'San-sage' in Okinawa Prefecture.
It is also called 'San-sage' in Okinawa Prefecture.

sen.j: C-F-B♭となる。
sen.e: The strings are tuned C-F-B♭.
The strings are tuned C-F-B♭.
The strings are tuned C-F-B♭.

sen.j: 伴奏する内容に合わせて幾つかの種類がある。
sen.e: There are several kinds of shamisen to play an accompaniment to different genres of music.
There are several kinds of shamisen used to play accompaniment to different genres of music.
There are several kinds of shamisen used to play accompaniment to different genres of music.

sen.j: 一般に、細棹・中棹・太棹に大別される。
sen.e: They are roughly classified in three categories in general: Hosozao (thinnest type of shamisen), Chuzao (a middle-size shamisen), and Futozao ("broad-neck" shamisen).
They are roughly classified in three categories in general: Hosozao (thinnest type of shamisen), Chuzao (a middle-size shamisen), and Futozao ("broad-neck" shamisen).
They are roughly classified in three categories in general: Hosozao (thinnest type of shamisen), Chuzao (a middle-size shamisen), and Futozao ("broad-neck" shamisen).

sen.j: 長唄三味線：細棹。
sen.e: Nagauta shamisen (shamisen used for nagauta, long epic song): Hosozao.
Nagauta shamisen (shamisen used for nagauta, long epic song): Hosozao.
Nagauta shamisen (shamisen used for nagauta, long epic song): Hosozao.

sen.j: 象牙製の撥を用いる。
sen.e: It is played with bachi made of ivory.
It is played with bachi made of ivory.
It is played with bachi made of ivory.

sen.j: 歌舞伎音楽等で使用。
sen.e: It is used for Kabuki (traditional performing art) music and others.
It is used for Kabuki (traditional performing art) music and others.
It is used for Kabuki (traditional performing art) music and others.

sen.j: 義太夫三味線：太棹。
sen.e: Gidayu shamisen (shamisen used for Gidayu, reciting dramatic narratives): Futozao.
Gidayu shamisen (shamisen used for Gidayu, reciting dramatic narratives): Futozao.

sen.j: 大きく厚い撥を用いる。
sen.e: It is played with big, thick bachi.

sen.j: 浄瑠璃等で使用。
sen.e: It is used for Joruri (Ballad drama) and others.

sen.j: 常磐津三味線：中棹。
sen.e: Tokiwazu shamisen (shamisen used for Tokiwazu theatrical music): Chuzao.
Tokiwazu shamisen (shamisen used for Tokiwazu theatrical music): Chuzao.

sen.j: 清元三味線：中棹。
sen.e: Kiyomoto shamisen (shamisen used for Kiyomoto, a performance of Joruri puppet play): Chuzao.
Kiyomoto shamisen (shamisen used for Kiyomoto, a performance of Joruri puppet play): Chuzao.

sen.j: 地歌三味線：中棹。
sen.e: Jiuta shamisen: Chuzao.
Jiuta shamisen: Chuzao.
Jiuta shamisen: Chuzao.

sen.j: 高いポジションを多用するため、棹の胴との接合部が他の三味線とは異なっている。
sen.e: Its joint between sao and do is different from other kinds of shamisen for frequent use of high notes.
sen.cmt: 原文の「高いポジション」は「高音部」と解釈して訳出しました。
sen.e: Its transition between sao and do is different from other kinds of shamisen during frequent use of high notes.
Its transition between sao and do is different from other kinds of shamisen during frequent use of high notes.

sen.j: 「津山撥」という象牙製の撥を用いる。
sen.e: It is played with ivory bachi called 'Tsuyama bachi.'
It is played with an ivory bachi called 'Tsuyama bachi.'
It is played with an ivory bachi called 'Tsuyama bachi.'

sen.j: 地歌の三味線自体は「三弦（三絃）」と呼ばれる事が多い。
sen.e: Shamisen for jiuta is often called 'sangen.'
Shamisen for jiuta is often called 'sangen.'

sen.j: 「三曲」とも呼ばれ、地歌及び箏・胡弓・尺八との合奏に使用。
sen.e: It is also called 'sankyoku,' and is used for playing music with jiuta, so (koto), kokyu, and shakuhachi (bamboo flute) as an ensemble.
sen.cmt: 前の文からの続きとすると、「地歌の三味線自体」が「三曲」と呼ばれているように読み取れ、事実とは違うように思いますが、原文どおり訳出しました。
sen.e: It is also called 'sankyoku,' and is used for playing music with jiuta, so (koto), kokyu, and shakuhachi (bamboo flute) as an ensemble.

sen.j: 新内三味線：中棹。
sen.e: Shinnai shamisen (shamisen used for Shinnai theatrical music): Chuzao.
sen.cmt: 原文には「新内節」とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「新内」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: Shinnai shamisen (shamisen used for Shinnai theatrical music): Chuzao.
Shinnai shamisen (shamisen used for Shinnai theatrical music): Chuzao.

sen.j: 爪を用い、立って演奏する「新内流し」が有名。
sen.e: It is famous for 'Shinnai nagashi' (Shinnai theatrical music played by a strolling musician) in which the musician plucks the strings with the fingernails and performs standing up.
It is famous for 'Shinnai nagashi' (Shinnai theatrical music played by a strolling musician) in which the musician plucks the strings with the fingernails and performs standing up.
It is famous for 'Shinnai nagashi' (Shinnai theatrical music played by a strolling musician) in which the musician plucks the strings with the fingernails and performs standing up.

sen.j: 柳川三味線（京三味線）：三味線の最も古い形。
sen.e: Yanagawa shamisen (Kyo shamisen): The oldest model of shamisen.
Yanagawa shamisen (Kyo shamisen): The oldest model of shamisen.
Yanagawa shamisen (Kyo shamisen): The oldest model of shamisen.

sen.j: 細棹より更に細い。
sen.e: It is thinner than Hosozao.

sen.j: 津軽三味線：太棹。
sen.e: Tsugaru-jamisen: Futozao.
Tsugaru-jamisen: Futozao.
Tsugaru-jamisen: Futozao.

sen.j: 先端が鼈甲製の小ぶりの撥を用いる。
sen.e: It is played with small bachi with the tip made of tortoiseshell.
It is played with small bachi that has a tip made of tortoiseshell.
It is played with small bachi that has a tip made of tortoiseshell.

sen.j: 津軽民謡の伴奏に使用。
sen.e: It is used to play an accompaniment to Tsugaru Minyo (a traditional folk song).
It is used to play accompaniment to Tsugaru Minyo (a traditional folk song).

sen.j: 三線（サンシン）：沖縄県と鹿児島県奄美諸島で用いられる。
sen.e: Sanshin: it is used in Okinawa Prefecture and Amami islands of Kagoshima Prefecture.
Sanshin: it is used in Okinawa Prefecture and the Amami islands of Kagoshima Prefecture.

sen.j: インドネシアニシキヘビの皮と、黒檀製漆塗りの棹に特徴がある。
sen.e: It is characterized by the skin of Indonesian python and the lacquered sao made of ebony.
It is characterized by the skin of an Indonesian python and a lacquered sao made of ebony.
It is characterized by the skin of an Indonesian python and a lacquered sao made of ebony.

sen.j: 撥は用いず、スイギュウの角で作られた爪で弾く。
sen.e: It is not played with bachi, but played with a nail made of the horn of a buffalo.
It is not played with bachi, but played with a nail made of the horn of a buffalo.
It is not played with bachi, but played with a nail made of the horn of a buffalo.

sen.j: ゴッタン：鹿児島県に残る楽器。
sen.e: Gottan (local shamisen of Kagoshima region): an instrument remains in Kagoshima Prefecture.
Gottan (local shamisen of Kagoshima region): one instrument remains in Kagoshima Prefecture.
Gottan (local shamisen of Kagoshima region): one instrument remains in Kagoshima Prefecture.

sen.j: 杉板で作られ、皮を張らずに板張りされている。
sen.e: It is made of cedar board and, instead of skin covering, is covered with the board.
It is made of cedar board and, instead of skin covering, is covered with the board.
It is made of cedar board and, instead of skin covering, is covered with the board.

sen.j: これ以外に、大正時代につくられたセロ三味線というものがある。
sen.e: In addition to them, there is 'selo shamisen' (a low-pitched sound shamisen) originated in the Taisho period.
In addition, there is 'selo shamisen' (a low-pitched sound shamisen) that originated in the Taisho period.

sen.j: 三味線は楽器分類学上「リュート属」に属する。
sen.e: According to the taxonomic classification of musical instruments, shamisen belongs to 'lute family.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the taxonomic classification of musical instruments, shamisen belongs to 'lute family.'
According to the taxonomic classification of musical instruments, shamisen belongs to 'lute family.'

sen.j: その中でも胴に長い棹を差し込んだ形状をしており、このような楽器は世界各地に見られ、ギターやシタールも同じ仲間と見なされている。
sen.e: Among others in the family, shamisen is shaped by inserting the neck into the body; instruments of this kind are seen all over the world, and a guitar and a sitar are deemed to be the same kind.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Among others in the family, shamisen is shaped by inserting the neck into the body; instruments of this kind are seen all over the world, and a guitar and a sitar are deemed to be the same type.
Among others in the family, shamisen is shaped by inserting the neck into the body; instruments of this kind are seen all over the world, and a guitar and a sitar are deemed to be the same type.

sen.j: いっぽう同じリュート属でも琵琶やリュートなど棹と胴が一体化もしくはそれに近いものとは別の系統とされる。
sen.e: On the other hand, instruments with the neck and the body united in a single body or something close to it, like biwa (Japanese lute) or lute, are considered to be of a different type, even in the same lute family.

On the other hand, instruments with the neck and the body united in a single body or something close to it, like biwa (Japanese lute) or lute, are considered to be of a different type, even within the same lute family.

On the other hand, instruments with the neck and the body united in a single body or something close to it, like biwa (Japanese lute) or lute, are considered to be of a different type, even within the same lute family.

sen.j: 楕円形の胴に革を張り、棒状の長い棹を取り付けたリュート属弦楽器は、すでに古代エジプトの壁画に見られる。
sen.e: Stringed instruments of lute family, which have an oval body covered with skin and attached to long cylindrical neck, were already drawn in wall paintings of ancient Egypt.
Stringed instruments of lute family, having an oval body covered with skin and attached to long cylindrical neck, were already drawn in wall paintings of ancient Egypt.
Stringed instruments of lute family, having an oval body covered with skin and attached to long cylindrical neck, were already drawn in wall paintings of ancient Egypt.

sen.j: しかしこれが三味線の直接的な祖先かどうかは分からない。
sen.e: But it's not known if this is the direct ancestor of shamisen.
But it's not known if this is the direct ancestor of shamisen.
But it's not known if this is the direct ancestor of shamisen.

sen.j: 一方同じような楽器が中国秦代にも現れ、やがて奚琴となり、トルコ族によって中東に伝えられてラバーブになった。
sen.e: On the other hand, an instrument of the same kind appeared in China in the period of Qin dynasty, which developed into haegeum and later became rabab when the Turks brought it to the Middle East.
On the other hand, an instrument of the same type appeared in China during the Qin dynasty, which developed into haegeum and later became rabab when the Turks brought it to the Middle East.
On the other hand, an instrument of the same type appeared in China during the Qin Dynasty, which developed into haegeum and later became rabab when the Turks brought it to the Middle East.

sen.j: このラバーブが後に中東及びイラン（ペルシャ）のシタールとなったという説がある（胡弓演奏家・原一男による「擦弦楽器奚琴起源説」）。
sen.e: There is a theory that the rabab developed into a sitar of the Middle East and Iran (Persia) ('Haegeum theory of the origin of bowed string instruments' by Kazuo HARA, a kokyu player).
There is a theory that the rabab developed into the sitar of the Middle East and Iran (Persia) ('Haegeum theory of the origin of bowed string instruments' by Kazuo HARA, a kokyu player).
There is a theory that the rabab developed into the sitar of the Middle East and Iran (Persia) ('Haegeum theory of the origin of bowed string instruments' by Kazuo HARA, a kokyu player).

sen.j: これは「3つの弦（糸）」の意であり、これが三味線の祖先とされる。
sen.e: Sitar means 'three strings' and is deemed to be the ancestor of shamisen.
Sitar means 'three strings' and is deemed to be the ancestor of shamisen.
Sitar means 'three strings' and is deemed to be the ancestor of shamisen.

sen.j: のち中国に入り、三弦（サンシェン）が生まれる。
sen.e: Later it was introduced into China and sanxian was born.
Later it was introduced into China and the sanxian was born.
Later it was introduced into China and the sanxian was born.

sen.j: 琉球王国と中国（福州）との貿易により琉球にもたらされ、三線（サンシン）となった。
sen.e: It was brought to Ryukyu through trade between the Ryukyu Kingdom and China (Fuzhou), and became sanshin.
It was brought to Ryukyu through trade between the Ryukyu Kingdom and China (Fuzhou), and became sanshin.
It was brought to Ryukyu through trade between the Ryukyu Kingdom and China (Fuzhou), and became sanshin.

sen.j: これが三味線の原型という説もある（中国の三弦そのものが琉球経由で日本に入ったとする説もある）が、その後三線は本土の三味線から逆影響を受けて完成した。
sen.e: Although some say that this is the original form of shamisen (another theory holds that Chinese sanxian itself was introduced to Japan by way of Ryukyu), sanshin was later perfected through the influence, in reverse, of shamisen in the mainland.

Although some say that this is the original form of shamisen (another theory holds that the Chinese sanxian was introduced to Japan by way of Ryukyu), the sanshin was later perfected through the influence, in reverse, of shamisen in the mainland.

Although some say that this is the original form of shamisen (another theory holds that the Chinese sanxian was introduced to Japan by way of Ryukyu), the sanshin was later perfected through the influence, in reverse, of shamisen in the mainland.

sen.j: このような理由にもより、沖縄県では今でも中国風に「サンシン」と呼んだり、日本風に「シャミセン」と呼んだり、二つの呼称が併存している。
sen.e: For these backgrounds, it is still called by two different names in Okinawa Prefecture: 'sanshin' in Chinese, and 'shamisen' in Japanese.
For these backgrounds, it is still called by two different names in Okinawa Prefecture: 'sanshin' in Chinese, and 'shamisen' in Japanese.
For these backgrounds, it is still called by two different names in Okinawa Prefecture: 'sanshin' in Chinese, and 'shamisen' in Japanese.

sen.j: 16世紀末、琉球貿易により堺市に中国の三弦がもたらされ、短期間の内に三味線へと改良された。
sen.e: In the end of the 16th century, Ryukyu trade brought Chinese sanxian into Sakai City, and it was improved in a short period to become shamisen.
At the end of the sixteenth century, Ryukyu trade brought Chinese sanxian into Sakai City, and it was improved in a short period to become shamisen.
At the end of the sixteenth century, Ryukyu trade brought Chinese sanxian into Sakai City, and it was improved in a short period to become shamisen.

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉が淀殿のために作らせた三味線「淀」が現存している。
sen.e: Shamisen named 'Yodo,' which was made for Yodo-dono (Lady Yodo) under the order of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, still exists.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Shamisen named 'Yodo,' which was made for Yodo-dono (Lady Yodo) under orders from Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, still exists.
Shamisen named 'Yodo,' which was made for Yodo-dono (Lady Yodo) under orders from Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, still exists.

sen.j: 華奢なものの、すでに基本的に現在の三味線とほとんど変わらない形状をしている。
sen.e: Although it is slender, its basic shape is nearly the same with today's shamisen already.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although it is slender, its basic shape is nearly the same as today's shamisen.
Although it is slender, its basic shape is nearly the same as today's shamisen.

sen.j: 外国楽器である三弦から三味線への改良に関しては、当道座の盲人音楽家との関連が重要である。
sen.e: For the improvement from sanxian as a foreign instrument to shamisen, blind musicians of Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind) played an important part.
For improvments made from sanxian as a foreign instrument to the shamisen, blind musicians of Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind) played an important part.
For improvements made from sanxian as a foreign instrument to the shamisen, blind musicians of Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind) played an important part.

sen.j: 三弦が義爪を使って弾奏していたのを改め、三味線の弾奏に彼らが専門としていた「平曲（平家琵琶）」の撥を援用したのもそのあらわれである。
sen.e: It is expressed in the change of plucking method: sanxian was plucked with giso (a pick shaped like a nail), but shamisen was plucked with bachi for 'Heikyoku' (the music played on Heike biwa as accompaniment for the recitation of Heike monogatari) which they specialized in.

It is expressed in the change of plucking method: sanxian was plucked with giso (a pick shaped like a nail), but shamisen was plucked with bachi for 'Heikyoku' (the music played on Heike biwa as accompaniment for the recitation of Heike monogatari) which they specialized in.

It is expressed in the change of plucking method: sanxian was plucked with giso (a pick shaped like a nail), but shamisen was plucked with bachi for 'Heikyoku' (the music played on Heike biwa as accompaniment for the recitation of Heike monogatari) which they specialized in.

sen.j: また琵琶の音色の持つ渋さや重厚感、劇的表現力などを、本来どちらかといえば軽妙な音色を持つ三味線に加えるために様々な工夫がなされたものと思われる。
sen.e: It is believed that various measures were tried for adding biwa's subdued, massive, and dramatic tone to shamisen, which originally had rather light tone.
It is believed that various measures were tried for adding biwa's subdued, massive, and dramatic tone to the shamisen, which originally had a rather light tone.
It is believed that various measures were tried for adding biwa's subdued, massive, and dramatic tone to the shamisen, which originally had a rather light tone.

sen.j: とくに石村検校は三味線の改良、芸術音楽化、地歌の成立に大きく関わった盲人音楽家であろうと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za) ISHIMURA, among blind musicians, was most involved in the improvement of shamisen, its development to art music, and creation of jiuta.

It is said that Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za) ISHIMURA, among blind musicians, were the most involved in the improvement of shamisen, its development to art music, and the creation of jiuta.

It is said that Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za) ISHIMURA, among blind musicians, were the most involved in the improvement of shamisen, its development to art music, and the creation of jiuta.

sen.j: こうして軽重哀楽を様々に幅広く表現することのできる楽器となり、江戸時代に入るとすぐ、石村検校らにより最初の三味線音楽種目である地歌が生まれる。
sen.e: In this way shamisen has acquired versatility of expression as an instrument to play wide range of melodies: light and heavy, sad and merry; and jiuta, the first item of shamisen music, was born by Kengyo ISHIMURA and others at the very beginning of Edo period.

In this way shamisen acquired a versatility of expression as an instrument to play a wide range of melodies: light and heavy, sad and merry; and jiuta, the first item of shamisen music, was born by Kengyo ISHIMURA and others at the very beginning of the Edo period.

In this way shamisen acquired a versatility of expression as an instrument to play a wide range of melodies: light and heavy, sad and merry; and jiuta, the first item of shamisen music, was born by Kengyo ISHIMURA and others at the very beginning of the Edo period.

sen.j: また語り物である浄瑠璃にも取り入れられ、三味線音楽は「歌いもの」「語り物」の二つの流れに大きく分かれ、更に分化を繰り返して大きく発展していく。
sen.e: Since shamisen was also adopted into a narrative called Joruri, shamisen music had been roughly divided in two: 'utai mono' (lyrical song) and 'katari mono' (narrative), and then they have repeated subdivision to develop much further.

Since shamisen was also adopted into a narrative called Joruri, shamisen music had been roughly divided in two: 'utai mono' (lyrical song) and 'katari mono' (narrative), and then they have repeated subdivisions that developed much further.

sen.j: また都市の芸術音楽から流行歌、やがて地方の民謡にまで盛んに使われるようになった。
sen.e: It came to be used for wide range of music, such as art music and popular songs in the cities, and later also for Minyo (a traditional folk song) in the countries.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It came to be used for a wide range of music, such as art music and popular songs in the cities, and later also for Minyo (a traditional folk song) in the countryside.
It came to be used for a wide range of music, such as art music and popular songs in the cities, and later also for Minyo (a traditional folk song) in the countryside.

sen.j: こうして様々な近世邦楽をリードし支え、それと同時に更なる改良が加えられ、日本を代表する弦楽器となった。
sen.e: Thus shamisen has led and supported various Japanese music of recent times, adding further improvements at the same time, and has become the leading stringed instrument of Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus shamisen has led and supported various Japanese music of recent times, adding further improvements at the same time, and has become the leading stringed instrument of Japan.
Thus shamisen has led and supported various Japanese music of recent times, adding further improvements at the same time, and has become the leading stringed instrument of Japan.

sen.j: 日本音楽史上、一般民衆が楽器を手にするのは、神楽の笛、太鼓、鈴を除けば、三味線を待たなければならなかった。
sen.e: In Japanese music history, common people never had any musical instruments, except for fue (Japanese flute), drum, and bell in kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines), until the appearance of shamisen.

In Japanese music history, common people never had any musical instruments, except for fue (Japanese flute), drum, and bell in kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines), until the appearance of the shamisen.

tit.e: Word and Phrase related to shamisen
Words and Phrases related to shamisen

sen.j: 相手を惑わすことを「三味線を弾く」という。
sen.e: Misleading others can be said 'shamisen o hiku' (to play shamisen) in other words.
Misleading others can be said 'shamisen o hiku' (to play shamisen) in other words.

sen.j: 本来は「口三味線を弾く」、つまり口で三味線の音色を真似る事から、偽物、虚言という意味。
sen.e: It was originally 'kuchijamisen o hiku' (to play oral shamisen), that is, to imitate the tones of shamisen, what it comes down to is an imitation or a lie.
It was originally 'kuchijamisen o hiku' (to play oral shamisen), that is, to imitate the tones of shamisen, what it comes down to is an imitation or a lie.
It was originally 'kuchijamisen o hiku' (to play oral shamisen), that is, to imitate the tones of shamisen, what it comes down to is an imitation or a lie.

sen.j: たとえば「マージャンで、実際の手とは全く異なる手が出来ているように言い、相手を油断させたり警戒させたりする」「モータースポーツの予選でのかけひきで、実力よりはるかに遅いタイムを出してライバルチームを油断させる」など。
sen.e: Examples are, 'in mah-jongg, saying to have a hand which is completely different from the real one, to put the opponents off their guard or set them on their guard,' or, 'in a preliminary match of motor sports, running in a far worse time than the real ability as a strategy for putting the rivals off their guard,' and so on.

Examples are, 'in mah-jongg, saying to have a hand which is completely different from the real one, to put the opponents off their guard or set them on their guard,' or, 'in a preliminary match of motor sports, running in a far worse time than the real ability as a strategy for putting the rivals off guard,' and so on.

sen.j: シャミセンガイは腕足動物門腕足綱無穴目シャミセンガイ科に属する動物。
sen.e: Shamisen gai (Lingula) is an animal belonging to Brachiopoda Phylum, Lingulata Class, 無穴目, Lingulidae Family.
sen.cmt: 「無穴目」定訳不明※用語検索で゛出てくる"Lingulida Order"は「舌殻目」のこと（wikipediaでシャミセンガイはそう分類されている）のようです。原文に従うため「無穴目」の英語名を探しましたが見つかりませんでしたので漢字表記としました。ちなみに、サイトによっては「無関節目」に分類しているものもあり、実際どの目に属するか不明です。
sen.e: Shamisen gai (Lingula) is an animal belonging to Brachiopoda Phylum, Lingulata Class, 無穴目, Lingulidae Family.
Shamisen gai (Lingula) is an animal belonging to Brachiopoda Phylum, Lingulata Class, 無穴目, Lingulidae Family.

sen.j: 殻を胴、長い尾を棹に見立てたもの。
sen.e: Its shells are likened to do, the long tail is likened to sao.
Its shells are likened to do, the long tail is likened to sao.
Its shells are likened to do, the long tail is likened to sao.

sen.j: ナズナ（アブラナ科の植物）の俗名として「ペンペン草」がある。
sen.e: Nazuna (shepherd's purse, a plant belonging to Brassicaceae) is popularly known as 'pen pen gusa (weed).'
Nazuna (shepherd's purse, a plant belonging to Brassicaceae) is popularly known as 'pen pen gusa (weed).'
Nazuna (shepherd's purse, a plant belonging to Brassicaceae) is popularly known as 'pen pen gusa (weed).'

sen.j: これは果実が三味線の撥に似ているため、三味線音の擬音「ペンペン」を冠したもの。
sen.e: Because its fruits look like bachi for shamisen, it is called by the name prefixed by 'pen pen,' imitative sound of shamisen.
Because its fruit resembles bachi used with shamisen, it is called by the name prefixed by 'pen pen,' imitative sound of shamisen.
Because its fruit resembles bachi used with shamisen, it is called by the name prefixed by 'pen pen,' imitative sound of shamisen.
